item.title: The World Bank has released its 2017 forecast for the Thai economy
item.description:
The 2016 Thailand Economic Monitor, published today by the World Bank, projects Thailand’s economic growth to reach 3.1% in 2016 and 3.2% in 2017, surpassing the previous year’s 2.8%. The report identifies private consumption and public investments, such as rail infrastructure projects, as primary growth drivers. Tourism has also performed well in 2016, with tourist arrivals, particularly from China, rising by 13.1% in the third quarter. A temporary slowdown and economic inactivity following the passing of HM King Bhumibol Adulyadej in October are anticipated to be partially counterbalanced by year-end holiday tax incentives for shopping and domestic tourism...

item.description:
Vietnam’s economy shows resilience due to strong domestic demand and export-focused manufacturing, as highlighted in the World Bank’s recent Taking Stock report. The country’s mid-term economic outlook appears positive, with GDP projected to grow by 6% in the current year. The report, a semi-annual assessment of Vietnam’s economic performance, notes that economic growth decelerated to 5.9% in the first nine months of the year. item.title: Overview and analysis of the relaunched negotiations for EU accession to the ECHR
item.description:
The potential inclusion of the EU into the ECHR has been a long-awaited development. With the necessary Treaty modifications in the Lisbon Treaty and a negotiated accession treaty by 2013, it appeared that the CJEU’s December 2014 ruling would solidify this union. However, the Court’s judgment (Opinion 2/13), which was subject to criticism on this blog, unexpectedly disrupted the accession process. However, the process was resurrected in 2019 and has advanced quickly since then...

item.title: Rights to due process and secondary protection
item.description:
By Steve Peers The initial Common European Asylum System (CEAS) legislation defined ‘subsidiary protection,’ which protects individuals ineligible for refugee status but shouldn’t be returned to their home country. However, other initial CEAS legislation, particularly the asylum procedures Directive, didn’t cover those seeking subsidiary protection or clarify the connection between refugee and subsidiary protection statuses. This gap has been addressed in several ways. Firstly, future second-phase CEAS legislation fully applies to subsidiary protection applicants and defines the relationship between refugee and subsidiary protection statuses...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/rights-to-due-process-and-secondary-protection/

item.title: Part 1: The Legal Framework - Should the EU impose sanctions on its Member States for violations of the rule of law and human rights?
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers, University of Essex As an EU law and human rights professor for over two decades, the topic of sanctioning Member States for human rights violations was once straightforward. The enforcement procedure (Article 7 TEU) was never used, making in-depth discussions unnecessary. My focus remained on practical issues like arrest warrants and asylum seekers. However, the landscape has shifted. Like Article 50, which also addresses the EU’s relationship with Member States, Article 7 seems hastily drafted without considering its practical application, possibly because its creators never anticipated its use...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/part-1-the-legal-framework-should-the-eu-impose-sanctions-on-its-member-states-for-violations-of-the-rule-of-law-and-human-rights/

item.title: Turning Junk Frequencies Into Gold
item.description:
The 2.4 GHz WiFi band we use every day wasn’t originally designed for WiFi at all. It was part of the ISM band - Industrial, Scientific, and Medical - a section of the radio spectrum designated for devices that unintentionally emit radiation as a byproduct of their operation. These bands, ranging from 6.78 MHz to 245 GHz, were meant for devices like microwave ovens, industrial heaters, and medical equipment. The 2...

item.title: The Great Repeal Bill and the Legacy of Henry VIII: Threatening Rights
item.description:
Joelle Grogan, Lecturer, Middlesex University The Great Repeal Bill is ironically named because it won’t actually repeal much EU law. Instead, when Brexit concludes, it will initially shift existing EU law into British law. While this maintains some stability during the transition, the bill also includes a concerning element: a Henry VIII clause. This clause, named after the king who gave himself sweeping legislative power, allows the government to alter primary legislation with minimal parliamentary scrutiny...

item.title: Sipping on the Trunk Lines
item.description:
The history of telephone trunks goes back to the early days of telephones. Trunks are lines that carry multiple phone conversations, initially connecting switchboards and switching offices. They’ve evolved from wire bundles to analog and now digital circuits, with T1, ISDN PRI, DS3, and SONET being common digital trunking services. However, SIP trunking is emerging as a popular alternative. Telephone trunking saves money by combining multiple phone lines into a single high-bandwidth connection...

item.title: VoIP Without The Internet
item.description:
Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP) emerged as an alternative telephone service that utilizes existing broadband connections for both internet and phone services. This allows providers to bypass fees associated with leasing traditional copper phone lines, leading to more attractive bundled packages for customers. Theoretically, the internet’s capacity should easily accommodate low-bandwidth voice data. However, this isn’t always the case in reality. Internet paths, much like highways, can become congested, leading to bandwidth constraints, transmission delays (latency), and dropped data packets, all of which disrupt real-time communication like phone calls...

item.title: Why is it important to pay attention to eConnect importing data with leading spaces?
item.description:
By Steve Endow A simple Dynamics GP customer query unexpectedly returned zero results, even though the customer existed in the system. Upon closer inspection, it was discovered that the customer ID had a leading space. While Dynamics GP prevents users from entering leading spaces directly, eConnect allows them during import. This discrepancy can cause issues when querying data, as SQL differentiates between values with and without leading spaces. This highlights the importance of trimming leading and trailing white space from data during integration...

item.title: T1 Lines to Support Enterprise VoIP
item.description:
T1 lines are commonly known for their ability to combine multiple phone calls onto a single line using Time Division Multiplexing (TDM). However, they can also be used for Voice over IP (VoIP) communication between company locations or to connect with the Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN) through gateways. Traditional T1 lines were designed to carry 24 simultaneous high-quality phone calls over a copper wire pair. Each call is digitized and placed into one of 24 eight-bit time slots, synchronized precisely using atomic clocks...

item.title: Generalized MPLS Improves Optical Networks
item.description:
Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a technology that accelerates network speeds and supports various protocols, including IP, ATM, Frame Relay, and SONET. It achieves this by encapsulating these protocols within its own tunnels upon entering the network and restoring them to their original format upon exit. Within the MPLS network, routing occurs based on simplified tags inserted into packet headers. Constructing this specialized network for transporting other network traffic offers the advantage of defining service classes...

item.title: Is it appropriate for the outcome of the European Parliament elections to dictate the selection of the next President of the European Commission, or are there valid concerns about this democratic process?
item.description:
It’s doubtful the European Court of Justice will decide the next European Commission President. Election laws typically set the stage but don’t directly determine the winner, although there are notable exceptions like the 2000 US election. The 2014 Commission President election is unique because the rules changed, and their interpretation is debated. Previously, the European Council appointed the President after European Parliament approval. The Treaty of Lisbon introduced new rules, applied for the first time, stating the Parliament “elects” the President based on the Council’s nomination, “taking account” of Parliament election results...

item.title: Is the free movement of people in the European Economic Area (EEA) distinct from that in the EU?
item.description:
Karin Fløistad: PhD Candidate, European University Institute; practicing lawyer at Norwegian law firm Simonsen Vogt Wiig The UK’s post-Brexit relationship with the EU often involves discussions about the free movement of people, with the EEA Agreement frequently cited as a potential model. This piece will analyze two key distinctions between the EEA Agreement’s approach to the free movement of people and that of full EU membership. The EEA Agreement integrates the EU’s single market with three members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA): Norway, Iceland, and Liechtenstein...

item.title: Migration of General Ledger Balances - Net Change Compared to Debit and Credit
item.description:
I was talking with a client yesterday about their General Ledger (GL) balances from before they started using our system in May. They were puzzled by the activity in a particular account from January to March, seeing only a $100 credit in January, a $50 debit in February, and a $200 credit in March. They wondered why each month didn’t show both debits and credits. It took me a moment to realize that, unlike my usual practice of migrating both debit and credit activity for complete GL history, someone else had migrated only the net change for each period from their old system...

item.title: The CJEU establishes significant limitations on the Commission's power to initiate actions.
item.description:

item.title: Please don't end my year...
item.description:
Let’s debunk some common misconceptions about year-end closing in Dynamics GP: Myth #1: All adjusting entries must be finalized before closing the General Ledger. This is false. Dynamics GP allows posting to the most recent historical year. After closing 2009, for instance, adjustments can still be made to it, just not to 2008. This requires enabling “allow posting to history” in GL setup and ensuring the fiscal period is open in Fiscal Period Setup...

item.title: Clearing the Dynamics GP User ID field on Terminal Servers
item.description:
This article addresses a known issue in Dynamics GP, specifically regarding user ID retention on Terminal Servers. While convenient for single users, this feature can be disruptive in multi-user environments. The issue arises when multiple users log in and out of Dynamics GP on a Terminal Server. The system tends to remember the last user’s ID, forcing subsequent users to manually replace it with their own. item.title: T1 PRI For Call Centers
item.description:
When deciding on phone service for your call center, digital options are essential. While individual analog lines work for small setups, they lack integration capabilities and become costly as you expand beyond a few lines. For call centers with 10-12 lines using traditional PBX systems, digital T1 carrier service is a cost-effective solution. T1 lines offer two configuration options: channelized and PRI (Primary Rate Interface). Channelized T1 provides 24 independent lines suitable for various call types but lacks advanced features like Caller ID...

item.title: Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport Offers Huge Advantages
item.description:
By: John Shepler Data can be moved in many ways. The new top choice is Fiber Optic Ethernet, known as EoF or Ethernet over Fiber, which offers excellent value. What is Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport? When fiber optic lines were first installed, Ethernet wasn’t a factor. The standard was SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), designed to carry existing DS1 and DS3 phone calls on fiber. Fiber offered significantly more bandwidth than copper twisted pair, microwave, or coaxial cable...

item.title: Shut Up That Screaming Cell Phone!

item.title: Yes, user names in Dynamics GP are case sensitive.
item.description:

item.title: Your Next Battery Is a Capacitor
item.description:
Benjamin Franklin’s experiment with capturing electricity in Leyden Jars, glass jars with foil conductors that store electric charge, laid the groundwork for modern battery technology. Today, researchers have developed ultracapacitors, like the Graphene Ultracapacitor from the University of Texas at Austin, which are essentially very small but powerful capacitors. These ultracapacitors use nanometer-thin dielectrics instead of bulky glass jars, allowing them to achieve farad-level capacitance, much higher than the picofarad capacity of a Leyden Jar...

item.title: No Longer Negotiable: The Rights of EU and UK Citizens Post-Brexit
item.description:

item.description:

item.title: GigE and FastE Bandwidth Services
item.description:

However, for those requiring substantial bandwidth, choices beyond these basic levels are necessary. Carrier Ethernet is becoming the preferred choice for medium to high bandwidth needs, replacing traditional DS3, T3, and SONET technologies. item.title: The German Constitutional Court's Role in EU Trade Policy: Analyzing the EU/Canada Trade Agreement
item.description:

item.title: Asynchronous Pulsed Radiated Incident Light Communications
item.description:
A novel approach to “community” networking systems is being explored, inspired by a naturally occurring form of interconnected free space optical communications. This method transmits data using nanometer wavelengths, which are unregulated and currently not monetized, requiring minimal energy. The underlying protocol, Asynchronous Pulsed Radiated Incident Light communications, falls under the Ultra Narrow Band (UNB) modulation category. It operates at a low bit rate, directly pulsing the lightwave emitter. Traditional free-space optics (FSO), while capable of high bandwidth over long distances, are limited to point-to-point connections...

item.title: Drobo Mr. Storage Roboto

item.title: Oh no! Transaction numbers are missing!
item.description:
Clients and coworkers occasionally reach out to me, worried about gaps in their transaction numbers within Dynamics GP (like bank transfers, journal entries, or invoices). It’s important to remember: there’s no need to panic! These gaps are normal. Think of it this way: Dynamics GP assigns numbers as transactions are created, not when they’re finalized. For instance, if three people start invoices, they’ll get numbers 1, 2, and 3. If the second person deletes their invoice before saving, the next invoice will be number 4, leaving a gap...

item.description:
The Beogram 4000 restoration is progressing well. Rebuilding the deck led to a successful initial power-up where the carriage moved to the correct position, but the arm wouldn’t lower. A visual inspection showed a disconnected thin grey wire from the SK3054 NPN power transistor (0TR4). Tracing the wiring and consulting the schematic revealed that the grey wire connected to the transistor’s emitter, responsible for bypassing a current-limiting resistor (7R1) during the arm’s initial descent...

item.title: Mistakes in Integration Design: Avoiding Interface Follies
item.description:
The author has encountered recurring issues with Dynamics GP integrations, primarily stemming from limitations in external systems rather than Dynamics GP itself. While acknowledging that all software has limitations, the author finds the encountered issues to be fundamental flaws in interface design. One instance involved importing employees from a widely used HR and payroll system into Dynamics GP. The client requested hourly imports to accommodate potential new hires. However, the HR system only allowed daily exports due to its reliance on a date-based comparison for changes, rather than a more precise date and time system...

item.title: Check Point has discovered a vulnerability in a preinstalled app on Xiaomi devices
item.description:
Slava Makkaveev, a researcher from cybersecurity firm Check Point Software, recently discovered a concerning security flaw in Xiaomi phones. This vulnerability was found within the pre-installed “Guard Provider” app (com.miui.guardprovider), designed to identify malware. Ironically, this app could allow attackers on the same Wi-Fi network to perform a man-in-the-middle (MiTM) attack. This type of attack enables the interception and copying of data transmitted between the phone and online services. Furthermore, by exploiting a third-party software development kit (SDK) update mechanism, attackers could potentially disable malware protection and inject malicious code...
Read The Full Article :https://Nexus-Security.github.io/check-point-has-discovered-a-vulnerability-in-a-preinstalled-app-on-xiaomi-devices/

item.title: The Philippines' economic outlook has improved according to the World Bank
item.description:

Within this system, safeguarding fundamental rights is paramount. Article 6 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU) establishes a three-pronged approach to fundamental rights protection: 1) the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, 2) the EU’s commitment to the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR), and 3) general principles of EU law derived from the ECHR and shared constitutional values of member states...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Rebuilding the PCBs
item.description:
Following the repair of the Beogram 4002 (5513)’s arm lowering and tracking mechanisms, the next stage of restoration involved the electronics and platter drive. As usual, the process commenced with the replacement of all electrolytic capacitors on the printed circuit boards (PCBs) with new, high-quality Japanese capacitors rated for 105 degrees Celsius. To ensure the DC motor operates smoothly and without speed variations, the RPM relay was upgraded to a modern, enclosed unit, and 25-turn precision trimmers were installed for precise RPM adjustment...

item.title: The UAE Central Bank has introduced raised marks on certain currency notes to assist individuals with visual impairments
item.description:
The Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates has introduced new AED1,000, AED20, and AED10 banknotes featuring raised tactile marks designed to assist people with visual impairments, according to the Emirates News Agency, WAM. These new banknotes incorporate tactile elements created using the intaglio printing method on their widths. The AED1,000 note now includes two sets of four horizontal lines, evenly spaced, on both the left and right edges. Similarly, the AED20 denomination features three distinct horizontal lines in the same position, while the AED10 denomination has two...
